principle.name: Audience-First Approach
principle.description: Always prioritize understanding and addressing the target audience's needs, pain points, and desires
principle.rationale: Copy that resonates with the audience's specific situation converts better than generic messaging

example.scenario: Writing copy for a productivity app
example.good: "Stop drowning in endless to-do lists that never get done"
example.bad: "Our app helps you manage tasks efficiently"

principle.name: Benefits Over Features
principle.description: Focus on what the product does for the customer, not what it is
principle.rationale: Customers buy outcomes and transformations, not features and specifications

example.bad: "50GB of secure cloud storage with 256-bit encryption"

principle.name: Clear Value Proposition
principle.description: Communicate the unique value and differentiation within the first few seconds
principle.rationale: Users decide to stay or leave within seconds, so value must be immediately clear

example.good: "Get twice the results in half the time with AI-powered analytics"

principle.name: Social Proof Integration
principle.description: Include credible testimonials, reviews, and trust indicators throughout copy
principle.rationale: Social proof reduces risk perception and builds trust with prospects

example.good: "Join 10,000+ businesses that increased revenue by 40% in 90 days"
example.bad: "Our service helps businesses grow their revenue"

principle.name: Urgency and Scarcity
principle.description: Create appropriate urgency without being manipulative or false
principle.rationale: Urgency motivates action and prevents procrastination when used ethically

example.good: "Early bird pricing ends Friday - save 40% on your first year"

convention.rule: Maintain consistent brand voice across all copy while adapting tone to context

guidelines.guideline: Research existing brand voice guidelines before writing
Adapt formality level to audience and platform
Use active voice for stronger, more direct messaging
Match emotional tone to the customer's journey stage

examples.good: Professional but approachable: "We'll help you tackle this challenge together"
examples.bad: Overly formal: "Our organization shall provide assistance in addressing your operational difficulties"

convention.rule: Create headlines that promise a clear benefit or solution to a specific problem

guidelines.guideline: Use numbers and specifics when possible
Include power words that evoke emotion
Keep headlines under 60 characters for email subjects

examples.good: "5 Proven Strategies to Double Your Email Open Rates in 30 Days"

convention.rule: Use action-oriented, specific language that reduces friction

guidelines.guideline: Remove or reduce risk with guarantees
Make the next step crystal clear

examples.good: "Start Your Free 14-Day Trial (No Credit Card Required)"

convention.rule: Structure emails for skimmability and mobile optimization

guidelines.guideline: Write compelling subject lines that avoid spam triggers
Personalize beyond just the name when possible

principle.name: loss_aversion
principle.description: People are more motivated to avoid losses than to achieve equivalent gains
principle.application: Frame offers in terms of what they'll miss out on
principle.example: "Don't let your competitors get ahead while you're still using outdated tools"

principle.name: reciprocity
principle.description: People feel obligated to return favors and value
principle.application: Provide valuable content or tools before asking for anything
principle.example: "Here's a free template that saved our clients $10,000+ in consulting fees"

principle.name: authority
principle.application: Highlight credentials, awards, media mentions, and expertise
principle.example: "Featured in Forbes, used by Fortune 500 companies"

principle.name: specificity
principle.description: Specific numbers and details are more believable than round numbers
principle.example: "Increased conversion rates by 23.7%" vs "Increased conversion rates significantly"

pitfall.description: Writing about features instead of benefits
pitfall.why_problematic: Customers don't care about what you built, they care about what it does for them
pitfall.correct_approach: Always connect features to customer outcomes and emotions

pitfall.description: Using jargon or industry terminology without explanation
pitfall.why_problematic: Creates barriers to understanding and excludes potential customers
pitfall.correct_approach: Use simple, clear language that a 12-year-old could understand

pitfall.why_problematic: Damages credibility and can lead to legal issues
pitfall.correct_approach: Use specific, verifiable claims backed by data or testimonials

pitfall.why_problematic: Most users read on mobile devices with limited attention spans
pitfall.correct_approach: Write shorter paragraphs, use bullet points, and test on mobile devices
Use one strong, clear primary CTA per page or email

guideline.rule: Test one element at a time for reliable results
Write for easy scanning and comprehension

techniques.technique: Use bullet points and numbered lists
Highlight key phrases with bold or italics
Keep sentences under 20 words when possible

guideline.rule: Balance keyword optimization with natural, compelling copy

best_practices.practice: Include keywords in headlines and first paragraph
Use semantic keywords and related terms
Write meta descriptions that encourage clicks
Optimize for featured snippets with question-based content

category.name: before_publishing
category.item: Read copy aloud for flow and clarity
Check all links and contact information
Test on multiple devices and browsers
Ensure CTA is prominent and clear

category.name: performance_tracking
category.item: Monitor key metrics (open rates, click rates, conversions)
Document what works for future campaigns
